partnerView.welcomeMessage: This view helps you understand where your partner is in her cycle and how to best support her.
partnerView.howToApproach: üí¨ How to Approach Her Right Now
partnerView.suggestionsIntro: Based on her current phase, here are activities that align well with her energy:
partnerView.hormoneExplanation: Her current hormonal state affects her energy, mood, and cognitive function. Understanding this helps you communicate and interact with her more effectively.

playDead.title: PLAY DEAD
playDead.subtitle: üêæ The last 2-3 days before her period - be extra careful!
dont: Suggest going out (she wants to stay in)

proceedWithCaution.title: PROCEED WITH EXTREME CAUTION
proceedWithCaution.subtitle: ü¶∫ She's in her sensitive phase - handle with care!
dont: Rush her (she moves at her own pace)
Minimize feelings (they're real, deal with it)

superhero.title: SHE'S A SUPERHERO
do: Support her goals (she can do anything)
Be intimate (trust us on this one)

focusMode.title: FOCUS MODE
do: Respect her focus (she's in the zone)
Support her work (she's getting things done)

estrogen.peak: - Enhances confidence, verbal skills, and cognitive function

progesterone.peak: - Promotes calmness, but may lower energy

powerPhase1.description: She's building energy and confidence. Great time for collaborative planning and starting new projects together.

manifestationPhase.description: She's at her peak! This is her time to shine. Support her in high-stakes situations and celebrate her confidence.
do: Encourage her to take on challenges

powerPhase2.description: She has excellent focus and endurance. Great time for deep work and completing projects together.

nurturePhase.description: She needs rest and self-care. This is a time for patience, understanding, and emotional support.

learnPage.title: üìö Understanding Hormonal Cycles
learnPage.subtitle: Learn how hormonal cycles work and why understanding them matters for everyone
learnPage.videoDescription: Watch Dr. Mindy Pelz explain the concept of hormonal cycle intelligence and why she says "I'm going to give you gold" when teaching about these powerful phases.
womenPoints: Understand your body's natural rhythms and work with them, not against them
Plan important activities during your peak performance phases
Honor your need for rest during the Nurture Phase
Make informed decisions about work, relationships, and self-care
Recognize that your cycle is a superpower, not a limitation
menPoints: Better understand and support the women in your life
Recognize that hormonal changes are natural and powerful
Plan collaborative activities during peak performance phases
Provide understanding and support during rest phases
Build stronger relationships through empathy and knowledge
learnPage.educationNote: This is knowledge that should be taught in high school. Understanding hormonal cycles helps everyone work together more effectively, build stronger relationships, and create more supportive environments at home and in the workplace.

educationalContent.title: üìö Understanding Hormonal Cycles
educationalContent.intro: Based on Dr. Mindy Pelz's research, the menstrual cycle is divided into four distinct phases, each with unique hormonal patterns that affect energy, mood, cognition, and performance. Understanding these phases helps both women and their partners, colleagues, and loved ones work together more effectively and build stronger, more supportive relationships.
takeaways: The cycle is a superpower, not a limitation. Understanding these phases helps work with the body's natural rhythms, not against them.
Plan strategically. Schedule important meetings, presentations, and high-stakes activities during the Manifestation Phase (Days 11-15) when cognitive function and confidence peak.
Honor the Nurture Phase. Rest and self-care during Days 20-28 are essential for hormonal balance and long-term health. This is a time for recovery, not pushing through.
Every phase has value. Each phase offers unique strengths - from building energy to peak performance to deep focus to rest. There's no "bad" phase, only different opportunities.

Knowledge empowers everyone. When partners, colleagues, and loved ones understand hormonal cycles, they can provide better support, plan collaborative activities more effectively, and build stronger relationships based on empathy and understanding.
This should be taught in high school. Understanding hormonal cycles is fundamental knowledge that benefits everyone - women, men, partners, and society as a whole.

powerPhase1.name: Power Phase 1
powerPhase1.description: Estrogen begins to rise, enhancing energy and cognitive functions. This is a time of building momentum.
whatHappens: Energy and mood begin to improve
powerPhase1.whyItMatters: This phase sets the foundation for peak performance. As estrogen rises, you gain clarity, energy, and confidence.

manifestationPhase.name: Manifestation Phase
manifestationPhase.description: PEAK PERFORMANCE! Estrogen peaks, testosterone surges, and progesterone slightly increases. This is your time to shine.
whatHappens: Brain power and verbal skills peak
manifestationPhase.whyItMatters: This is your superpower phase. Your brain is operating at maximum capacity, making it the ideal time for important presentations, negotiations, creative work, and high-stakes activities.

powerPhase2.name: Power Phase 2
powerPhase2.description: Estrogen drops while progesterone rises, supporting focus and endurance. Great for deep work and follow-through.
powerPhase2.whyItMatters: While not as flashy as the Manifestation Phase, this is excellent for sustained focus, problem-solving, and completing complex projects.

nurturePhase.name: Nurture Phase
nurturePhase.description: Progesterone dominates, promoting rest and rejuvenation. This is a time for self-care and reflection.
whatHappens: Increased need for rest and recovery
nurturePhase.whyItMatters: This phase is crucial for recovery and preparation for the next cycle. Resting during this time supports hormonal balance and overall health.

estrogen.name: Estrogen
estrogen.description: A primary female sex hormone that plays a crucial role in the menstrual cycle and overall health.
estrogen.systems: Regulates reproductive system, brain function, bone health, cardiovascular system, and skin health.
estrogen.rising: When rising: You may feel more energetic, confident, and mentally sharp. Mood improves, verbal skills enhance, and you feel more social and optimistic.
estrogen.falling: When falling: Energy may decrease, mood can become more introspective, and you may feel less confident or more sensitive.

progesterone.name: Progesterone
progesterone.description: A hormone that prepares the body for pregnancy and helps maintain the uterine lining.
progesterone.systems: Regulates reproductive system, sleep quality, mood stability, and supports pregnancy if it occurs.
progesterone.rising: When rising: You may feel calmer, more focused, and introspective. Sleep quality improves, and you have better sustained attention for deep work.
progesterone.falling: When falling: You may feel more alert and energetic, but also potentially more anxious or restless. This signals the body to prepare for menstruation.

testosterone.name: Testosterone
testosterone.description: A hormone present in both women and men, though in different amounts. In women, it supports energy, libido, and assertiveness.
testosterone.systems: Regulates libido, muscle mass, bone density, energy levels, confidence, and assertiveness.
testosterone.rising: When rising: You may feel more confident, assertive, and competitive. Libido increases, energy peaks, and you feel more motivated to take on challenges.
testosterone.falling: When falling: You may feel less driven, more introspective, and prefer quieter activities. Energy for high-intensity activities decreases.
